The IntelliJ plugin seems out of date.

text: I'm kinda frustrated with emacs, but never been able to give anything else a solid try. I sometimes think modal editing would be nice. I know it's possible with emacs, but again, never gave it a solid try. Also, some ide-like features are missing or hard to set up... I guess (never really used an IDE)

elements.text: I'm kinda frustrated with emacs, but never been able to give anything else a solid try. I sometimes think modal editing would be nice. I know it's possible with emacs, but again, never gave it a solid try. Also, some ide-like features are missing or hard to set up... I guess (never really used an IDE)

text: I just use VSCode. It's nice if you do cross platform dev because there's no context shift. Supports all languages I use, has nice extensions, and works with minimal fuss. If that's off the table I mean, you're probably best off using VIM or Emacs.

elements.text: I just use VSCode. It's nice if you do cross platform dev because there's no context shift. Supports all languages I use, has nice extensions, and works with minimal fuss. If that's off the table I mean, you're probably best off using VIM or Emacs.

text: I really love emacs. There are some things it's not good at, but I can't stand to use any other IDE anymore.

elements.text: I really love emacs. There are some things it's not good at, but I can't stand to use any other IDE anymore.

text: <@U93BUBZP0> Have you heard of evil? It basically gives emacs, the power of vim (atleast that's what I've heard, never have been a fan of emacs personally :P).

elements.text: Have you heard of evil? It basically gives emacs, the power of vim (atleast that's what I've heard, never have been a fan of emacs personally :P).

text: I use VSCode or even like Micro. Tbh I find that with dynamic languages like Julia I don't miss plugins.

yep, rust-analyzer for Rust is also invaluable. I'm super thankful for the ppl making
julia-vscode
don't get me wrong, but using Rust/Haskell makes me wish so badly that Julia had static analysis.

text:
it actually makes learning a language a lot easier.
For haskell the tool tips actually give refactoring advice it's insane. Like I've learned to write better code by basically getting minicode reviews from a little plugin lol

elements.text:
it actually makes learning a language a lot easier.

text:
There is a trifecta of features I have never seen in an editor, but which would be an awesome combo:
* Terminal based
* Sane shortcuts as you would expect
* Support for LSP and plugins
Edit: Micro have the first two but lacks the latter. Emacs and vim lack the middle. VSCode lacks the first.

elements.text:
There is a trifecta of features I have never seen in an editor, but which would be an awesome combo:
* Terminal based
* Sane shortcuts as you would expect
* Support for LSP and plugins
Edit: Micro have the first two but lacks the latter. Emacs and vim lack the middle. VSCode lacks the first.

text: Well, while emacs can be used just fine from the terminal, almost nobody recommends it. The emacs GUI is great and basically what a terminal should have been by the year 2000.

elements.text: Well, while emacs can be used just fine from the terminal, almost nobody recommends it. The emacs GUI is great and basically what a terminal should have been by the year 2000.

text: I'd use pure terminal based stuff if the shortcuts weren't so darn weird

text: It always blows my mind how old emacs is. Older than the ‘sane shortcuts as you would expect’

text: You can customise any emacs keybinding, so also middle point is covered

text: And if you're referring to default keybindings, no one uses emacs with the default settings and no customisation at all (why would you use emacs otherwise?) and it's virtually impossible to find two users with the identical setup

elements.text: And if you're referring to default keybindings, no one uses emacs with the default settings and no customisation at all (why would you use emacs otherwise?) and it's virtually impossible to find two users with the identical setup

text: You almost never need to access a remote computer’s emacs editor because you can just use your local emacs to access a remote computer (via ssh or another protocol of your choice) with TRAMP.

elements.text: You almost never need to access a remote computer’s emacs editor because you can just use your local emacs to access a remote computer (via ssh or another protocol of your choice) with TRAMP.

text: Any computer in the internet is just an extension of your file system

text: I very much like to be aware of when a read hits the network :sweat_smile:

elements.text: I very much like to be aware of when a read hits the network

text: Right, I guess emacs can be customized in any fashion. It's just a lot of work up-front, without any guarantee that it'll have the potential to behave even close to normal after all that.

elements.text: Right, I guess emacs can be customized in any fashion. It's just a lot of work up-front, without any guarantee that it'll have the potential to behave even close to normal after all that.

text: is there a reason why your IDE needs to be terminal based? Does your computer not have enough RAM?

elements.text: is there a reason why your IDE needs to be terminal based? Does your computer not have enough RAM?

text: vscode lets you have multiple file windows open, multiple terminals, plots, etc. I just don't see why people need to be in a terminal except for habit or something

elements.text: vscode lets you have multiple file windows open, multiple terminals, plots, etc. I just don't see why people need to be in a terminal except for habit or something

text: It doesn't really *need* to be, it's just nicer to have it as a terminal tab or terminal window. And then it also starts instantly, and never crashes because of some weird plugin issue.

need
to be, it's just nicer to have it as a terminal tab or terminal window. And then it also starts instantly, and never crashes because of some weird plugin issue.

text: yea maybe once every 3-4 months VSCode will crash on me for VSCode reasons thats true.

text: I mostly use vscode but I get it. Terminals are pretty, and because each window does (in theory) exactly one thing, easily composable.
